results.title: Songs of innocence: a child's view of family life
results.creator_credit: Gordon Glenn, Patricia Edgar and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: 13 young children of varying ages share their delightfully frank observations about events that have changed their lives. Danielle, 10, attends the birth of her new sibling. Angus, 6, has just received a new baby sister and it’s affecting the amount of time he gets to spend with mum. Nicholas, 9, and his sister have an upbringing that involves a lot of musical and sporting extra curricular activities. Three Turkish sisters Pelin, Sermin, Suna have lived in an inner city high-rise since emigrating from Turkey 8 years ago. Kendel, 11, is an only child with parents who work long hours. Andrew and Sarah have parents who both work and discuss routines and discipline. Tessie, 8, lives with her mother following her parent’s divorce. She describes what it was like when her father left and when her mother started seeing someone else. Richard, 12, has lived with his father since his parents divorced and his father is about to remarry. Troy (13) and Amanda (12) live with their grandmother and aunt. Their mother lives in New Zealand and they didn’t know their fathers. Speaking with candour, the children show remarkable insight into the dynamics of the family. Please note: child birth scene

results.title: Son of the ocean
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Parker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
One of the grandest links in China’s network of waterways is the Yangtze River. The river was closed to foreigners in 1949. In this riverboat journey we travel through the Yangtze Gorges on the way from Chungking to Wuhan and the story of the boat crew and passengers unfolds. Narrated by John Bell. Contains Chinese language with English subtitles. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Songs from Lift-off
results.creator_credit: Steve Steve Jodrell, Patricia Edgar and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: This video contains a collection of songs from the children’s series Lift off, including “The Lift off ” (series theme song), “Into the unknown”, “Lost”, “Do you remember?”, “Which one?”, “Bonza jingle”. All the favourite Lift off characters appear in the collection.

results.title: It is always so in the world
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
Shanghai in 1979, with its 11 million people, and the second biggest city in the world, was for years dominated by foreign powers. Following the end of the revolution in the early 1970s, China is now caught up in the urgency to accelerate progress and this is expressed by a massive campaign to make everyone personally committed to the aim of the 4 modernisations: to catch up with the west in science, education, agriculture and defence by the year 2000.

results.title: Mind, body and spirit
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of China”.
The medical services for China’s rural people - 80% of the population - were built upon the integration of Chinese traditional and western medical practices. Most basic health care needs can be met by the barefoot doctors. In Chienchou People’s Commune we seethe role played by two of these doctors. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels. Narrated by John Bell. “With thanks to the Central Newsreel and Documentary Film Studio of the People’s Republic of China.”

results.title: Song of the south
results.creator_credit: Harve Foster, Wilfred Jackson, Perce Pearce, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: In the years just after the Civil War, young Johnny (Bobby Driscoll) is sent to live at the southern plantation of his grandmother (Lucile Watson) while his parents contemplate divorce. At first disconsolate, the boy is cheered up by African-American handyman Uncle Remus (James Baskett), who tells him many delightful fables concerning the clever trickster Br’er Rabbit, whose adventures are illustrated in cartoon form. Based on the popular ‘Uncle Remus’ stories of Joel Chandler Harris and blending live action with cell animation, ‘Song of the South’ is an American classic, both loved for its popular songs and seamless technique, and reviled for its condescending depiction of African-Americans. Also starring Hattie MacDaniel.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harve Foster, Wilfred Jackson, Perce Pearce, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Pictures

results.title: The Lau of Malaita
results.creator_credit: Leslie Woodhead and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Disappearing world”.
Episode 4 of this five part series looks at the story of the people of the Lau Lagoon. 600 years ago in the Solomon Islands, the Lau people abandoned the hills of Malaita to start a new life, incredibly, by constructing small coral islands in the idyllic Pacific lagoon below. Today most of the 60 island communities in the Lau Lagoon have come under Christian missionary influence which has transformed their entire system of beliefs and values and replaced the original “life of custom”. This program shows the villagers taking positive steps to revive their dying traditions.

results.title: Song of the shirt
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Curling, Sue Clayton and Film and History Project
results.brief_description: An examination of the clothing industry in mid nineteenth century England, its organisation, the distribution and exploitation of female labour, and the representation of this process in the media. Using dramatised scenes, stills and video material, this traces the development of a chain of seamstresses’ workshops, linked to a central wholesaler. The system, in force from the 1830’s onwards, is shown to depend on the rigorous subdivision of labour and the principle of paying just enough to keep the labour force above the starvation level. The films is divided into 3 parts, plus postscript, each dealing with one aspect of the total history. Cast includes Martha Gibson, Paul Bentel, Geraldine Pilgrim, Frazer Cains and Anne McNiff.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jonathan Curling, Sue Clayton and Film and History Project

results.title: The Kawelka Ongka's Big Moka
results.creator_credit: Charles Nairn and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Disappearing world”.
In the West Highlands of Papua New Guinea there are many tribes. One of them is the Kawelka. The most prominent leader or ‘big man’ of the Kawelka tribe is called Ongka. For five years the Kawelka, driven on by Ongka, have been struggling to assemble a huge gift (a Moka) to give to a neighbouring tribe. For Ongka, assembling and giving this gift is more important than anything in his life. But when a big man dies suddenly in Ongka’s enemy tribe things start to go wrong.

results.title: The Mehinacu
results.creator_credit: Carlos Pasini and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Disappearing world”.
The men and women of the Mehinacu, in central Brazil, live harmoniously in the five family houses of their small village, but conflict and separation of the sexes is an everyday fact of life - with the men and women performing distinctly different roles and tasks in order to thrive together. This film is a record of the elaborate rituals that take a month to complete, and are central to the Mehinacu way of life - a unique and colourful system of custom and taboo that may not survive the modern world.
